description: From Middle English preye, prei, preyȝe, borrowed from Anglo-Norman and Old French preie, one of the variants of proie, from Latin praeda. Compare predator.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Anything, such as goods, etc., taken or got by violence; something taken by force from an enemy in war
That which is or may be seized by animals or birds to be devoured
examples: Already sees herself the monster's prey.

entries.meaning: A person or thing given up as a victim.
A living thing that is eaten by another living thing.
examples: The rabbit was eaten by the coyote, so the rabbit is the coyote's prey.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The act of devouring other creatures; ravage.

verbs.description: prey (third-person singular simple present preys, present participle preying, simple past and past participle preyed)

examples: The ridge had been a haven for birds and small earth creatures, creeping, crawling, and hopping in a little world of balanced ecology where wild things preyed and were preyed upon  […]
